title: Isaiah Chapter 61 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Isaiah chapter 61 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Isaiah Chapter 61 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Isaiah Chapter 61.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 61:1, who is upon the speaker?
options: The Spirit of the Lord GOD
questions.correctAnswer: The Spirit of the Lord GOD
questions.explanation: Isaiah 61:1 states, 'The Spirit of the Lord GOD is upon me,' indicating that the Spirit is upon the speaker.

questions.question: What mission was given to the speaker in Isaiah 61:1?
options: To preach good tidings to the meek
questions.correctAnswer: To preach good tidings to the meek
questions.explanation: Isaiah 61:1 says, 'because the LORD hath anointed me to preach good tidings unto the meek.'

questions.question: Isaiah 61:2 mentions proclaiming the acceptable year of the LORD and what other event?
options: The day of vengeance of our God
The day of peace for Israel
questions.correctAnswer: The day of vengeance of our God
questions.explanation: Isaiah 61:2 states the mission includes proclaiming 'the acceptable year of the LORD, and the day of vengeance of our God.'

questions.question: What will be given to those who mourn in Zion according to Isaiah 61:3?
options: Beauty for ashes, oil of joy for mourning, garment of praise
Gold and silver as a reward
A new city to dwell in
questions.correctAnswer: Beauty for ashes, oil of joy for mourning, garment of praise
questions.explanation: Isaiah 61:3 promises 'to give unto them beauty for ashes, the oil of joy for mourning, the garment of praise for the spirit of heaviness.'

questions.question: According to Isaiah 61:4, what will they build up?
options: The old wastes and former desolations
A great wall around the city
questions.correctAnswer: The old wastes and former desolations
questions.explanation: Isaiah 61:4 states, 'they shall build the old wastes, they shall raise up the former desolations.'

questions.question: Who shall stand and feed your flocks according to Isaiah 61:5?
questions.correctAnswer: Strangers
questions.explanation: Isaiah 61:5 says, 'strangers shall stand and feed your flocks.'

questions.question: In Isaiah 61:6, what name will be given to the people?
questions.correctAnswer: Priests of the LORD
questions.explanation: Isaiah 61:6 states, 'ye shall be named the Priests of the LORD.'

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 61:7 says the people will receive a double portion for their shame.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 61:7 says, 'For your shame ye shall have double.'

questions.question: What does the LORD hate according to Isaiah 61:8?
questions.correctAnswer: Robbery for burnt offering
questions.explanation: Isaiah 61:8 states, 'I hate robbery for burnt offering.'

questions.question: According to Isaiah 61:9, what will be known among the Gentiles?
questions.correctAnswer: Their seed and offspring
questions.explanation: Isaiah 61:9 says, 'their seed shall be known among the Gentiles, and their offspring among the people.'

questions.question: What does the speaker rejoice in according to Isaiah 61:10?
options: The LORD and the garments of salvation
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD and the garments of salvation
questions.explanation: Isaiah 61:10 says, 'I will greatly rejoice in the LORD, my soul shall be joyful in my God; for he hath clothed me with the garments of salvation.'

questions.question: Complete this verse from Isaiah 61:11: 'For as the earth bringeth forth her bud, and as the garden causeth the things that are sown in it to ______.'
questions.correctAnswer: spring forth
questions.explanation: Isaiah 61:11 states, 'as the garden causeth the things that are sown in it to spring forth.'

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 61:3 describes those who mourn as 'trees of righteousness.'
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 61:3 says that those who mourn 'might be called trees of righteousness, the planting of the LORD.'

questions.question: According to Isaiah 61:6, what will the people eat?
questions.correctAnswer: The riches of the Gentiles
questions.explanation: Isaiah 61:6 says, 'ye shall eat the riches of the Gentiles.'

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 61:2 states that the speaker was sent to comfort all that mourn.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 61:2 includes the mission 'to comfort all that mourn.'

medium.title: Isaiah Chapter 61 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Isaiah Chapter 61 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Isaiah 61, what biblical truth would you share about God’s role in comforting the brokenhearted?
options: God sends His Spirit to bind up the brokenhearted and proclaim liberty to captives.
God allows trials without any promise of comfort or deliverance.
God expects believers to handle their brokenness on their own.
God only comforts the strong and successful believers.
questions.correctAnswer: God sends His Spirit to bind up the brokenhearted and proclaim liberty to captives.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 61:1 speaks of the Spirit of the Lord being upon the messenger to bind up the brokenhearted and proclaim liberty, showing God's active role in comforting and delivering those in distress. This is supported by verses 2 and 3 which speak of comforting all that mourn and giving beauty for ashes.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 61 teach about God’s faithfulness in restoring and rebuilding after hardship?
options: God promises that His people will build the old wastes and repair desolate cities.
God leaves the ruins as a reminder of past failures.
God expects people to forget their past and move on without restoration.
God requires people to rebuild alone without His help.
questions.correctAnswer: God promises that His people will build the old wastes and repair desolate cities.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 61:4 clearly states that God’s people shall build the old wastes and repair the desolations, indicating God’s promise of restoration and rebuilding after trials. This aligns with verses 7 and 8 which speak of double blessings and an everlasting covenant.

questions.question: A believer feels ashamed because of past sins. What hope does Isaiah 61 offer regarding shame and joy?
options: For shame, they shall have double; and for confusion, they shall rejoice.
Shame is a permanent mark and cannot be removed.
Joy comes only after we are perfect and without sin.
Shame must be endured without hope of joy.
questions.correctAnswer: For shame, they shall have double; and for confusion, they shall rejoice.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 61:7 promises double for shame and joy for confusion, showing God’s grace in transforming shame into rejoicing. Verse 10 also supports this with rejoicing in salvation and being clothed with righteousness.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 61 encourage believers to live with integrity and honesty in their work?
options: The LORD loves judgment and hates robbery for burnt offering; He directs their work in truth.
The LORD overlooks dishonest gain if it benefits His people.
Work is unimportant compared to spiritual matters.
Honesty is optional when serving God.
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD loves judgment and hates robbery for burnt offering; He directs their work in truth.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 61:8 emphasizes God’s love for justice and truthfulness in work, instructing believers to maintain honesty and integrity, which is foundational for Christian living. This is consistent with the overall theme of righteousness in verses 6 and 11.

questions.question: Based on Isaiah 61, how should believers view their identity and calling in serving God?
options: They shall be called priests of the LORD and ministers of God.
They have no special role or identity in God’s work.
Their calling is only to serve themselves.
Believers are only observers, not participants in God’s work.
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be called priests of the LORD and ministers of God.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 61:6 reveals that believers are named priests and ministers of God, emphasizing a sacred identity and responsibility in serving Him, which encourages faithful service and spiritual discipline.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 61 teach about rejoicing in God’s salvation and righteousness?
options: The soul rejoices greatly, being clothed with garments of salvation and robes of righteousness.
Rejoicing is discouraged until the end of life.
Salvation and righteousness are hidden and private matters.
Joy in God’s salvation is only for a select few.
questions.correctAnswer: The soul rejoices greatly, being clothed with garments of salvation and robes of righteousness.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 61:10 describes rejoicing in the LORD and being clothed with salvation and righteousness, portraying joy as a natural response to God’s grace and provision, which should encourage believers in daily devotion and gratitude.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with mourning and heaviness. According to Isaiah 61, what spiritual transformation does God promise?
options: Giving beauty for ashes, oil of joy for mourning, and garments of praise for the spirit of heaviness.
Mourning must continue without relief to build character.
God ignores those who mourn and focuses on the joyful only.
Mourning is a sign of weak faith and is not addressed by God.
questions.correctAnswer: Giving beauty for ashes, oil of joy for mourning, and garments of praise for the spirit of heaviness.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 61:3 promises a divine exchange of sorrow for joy and praise, providing hope and encouragement for believers facing grief, supporting perseverance and spiritual renewal.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 61 teaches that God’s blessings include prosperity and honor among the nations.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 61:9 states that their seed shall be known among the Gentiles and acknowledged as blessed by the LORD, indicating that God’s blessings extend to prosperity and honor in the sight of others.

questions.question: True or False: According to Isaiah 61, God’s covenant with His people is temporary and conditional.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 61:8 speaks of an everlasting covenant made by the LORD, highlighting the enduring and faithful nature of God’s promises to His people.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Isaiah 61 teaches that God will cause righteousness and _______ to spring forth before all the nations.
questions.correctAnswer: praise
questions.explanation: Isaiah 61:11 states that the Lord GOD will cause righteousness and praise to spring forth before all nations, emphasizing the importance of both justice and worship in God’s kingdom.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 61 describe the role of foreigners and strangers in the community of God’s people?
options: Strangers shall stand and feed your flocks, and the sons of the alien shall be your plowmen and vinedressers.
Strangers will be excluded and have no role in God’s people.
God’s people must always be self-reliant and not depend on others.
Foreigners are to be avoided to keep the community pure.
questions.correctAnswer: Strangers shall stand and feed your flocks, and the sons of the alien shall be your plowmen and vinedressers.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 61:5 highlights the inclusion of strangers and aliens in the work and community of God’s people, which teaches cooperation, humility, and the value of all laborers in God’s work.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged about their witness to the nations. What encouragement does Isaiah 61 offer about their spiritual legacy?
options: Their seed shall be known among the Gentiles and acknowledged as blessed by the LORD.
Their witness will be largely ignored by other nations.
They have no responsibility to influence others outside their community.
Their legacy depends only on earthly achievements.
questions.correctAnswer: Their seed shall be known among the Gentiles and acknowledged as blessed by the LORD.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 61:9 affirms that God’s people and their descendants will be recognized and blessed among the nations, encouraging believers to persevere in evangelism and faithful living.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 61 model a spirit of gratitude and joy in personal devotion to God?
options: The soul rejoices greatly in God, clothed with salvation and righteousness like a bride adorned with jewels.
Joy and gratitude are optional and unrelated to devotion.
Devotion is primarily about duty and not about joy.
God’s blessings are to be taken for granted.
questions.correctAnswer: The soul rejoices greatly in God, clothed with salvation and righteousness like a bride adorned with jewels.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 61:10 uses the imagery of joyful adornment to illustrate how believers should rejoice and be grateful in their relationship with God, underscoring the importance of heartfelt worship and thankfulness.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 61 teach about the effect of God's Spirit upon the messenger's mission?
options: The Spirit of the Lord anoints to preach good tidings, bind up the brokenhearted, and proclaim liberty.
The Spirit causes the messenger to work in isolation without support.
The Spirit focuses only on judgment and punishment.
The Spirit requires the messenger to remain silent.
questions.correctAnswer: The Spirit of the Lord anoints to preach good tidings, bind up the brokenhearted, and proclaim liberty.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 61:1 describes the Spirit’s anointing to empower the messenger to bring hope and freedom, setting a model for Christian witness and ministry to others.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 61 describe the transformation of those who mourn in Zion?
options: They receive beauty for ashes, oil of joy for mourning, and garments of praise for heaviness.
They remain in their mourning indefinitely.
They must hide their sorrow and never express it.
They are left to suffer without comfort.
questions.correctAnswer: They receive beauty for ashes, oil of joy for mourning, and garments of praise for heaviness.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 61:3 promises God’s transformative comfort for those who mourn, encouraging believers to trust in His power to change sorrow into praise and joy.

hard.title: Isaiah Chapter 61 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Isaiah Chapter 61.

questions.question: In Isaiah 61:1, the phrase 'The Spirit of the Lord GOD is upon me' is a direct allusion to which Old Testament prophetic commissioning?
options: The calling of Moses at the burning bush
The commissioning of the prophet Isaiah in Isaiah 6
The Spirit coming upon Samson in Judges
questions.correctAnswer: The commissioning of the prophet Isaiah in Isaiah 6
questions.explanation: Isaiah 61:1 echoes Isaiah 6 where the prophet is commissioned by God, emphasizing the Spirit's empowerment for mission.

questions.question: The 'acceptable year of the LORD' mentioned in Isaiah 61:2 is best understood as a reference to which ancient Hebrew concept?
options: The Jubilee year of liberation and restoration
questions.correctAnswer: The Jubilee year of liberation and restoration
questions.explanation: Isaiah 61:2 uses 'acceptable year' as a typological reference to the Jubilee year described in Leviticus 25, a time of freedom and restoration.

questions.question: What literary device is predominantly used in Isaiah 61:3 when contrasting 'beauty for ashes' and 'oil of joy for mourning'?
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: Isaiah 61:3 employs parallelism, a common Hebrew poetic device, juxtaposing contrasting images to emphasize transformation.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 61:4, what is the significance of rebuilding 'the old wastes' and repairing 'waste cities' in the historical context of Israel?
questions.correctAnswer: Restoration after Babylonian exile
questions.explanation: The verse reflects the historical period after Babylonian exile when the Israelites returned to rebuild Jerusalem and its surroundings.

questions.question: Isaiah 61:5 refers to 'strangers' and 'sons of the alien' working the land. What does this indicate about the socio-economic context anticipated by the prophet?
options: Inclusion of Gentiles in Israel's restoration
questions.correctAnswer: Inclusion of Gentiles in Israel's restoration
questions.explanation: This verse anticipates a future where Gentiles will serve and partake in Israel’s blessings, signaling inclusion and expanded covenant community.

questions.question: The title 'Priests of the LORD' in Isaiah 61:6 serves to foreshadow which New Testament concept?
questions.correctAnswer: The priesthood of all believers
questions.explanation: Isaiah 61:6 anticipates a spiritual priesthood extended to all God's people, a concept developed in the New Testament (e.g., 1 Peter 2:9).

questions.question: In Isaiah 61:7, the promise of receiving 'double' for shame carries what theological implication?
options: Divine restitution and blessing exceeding past suffering
questions.correctAnswer: Divine restitution and blessing exceeding past suffering
questions.explanation: The 'double' signifies God's restorative justice, compensating the people abundantly for their former shame and loss.

questions.question: Isaiah 61:8 states, 'I the LORD love judgment, I hate robbery for burnt offering.' What does this reveal about God's character and covenant expectations?
options: God desires justice over empty ritual sacrifices
God rejects all forms of sacrifice
God is indifferent to human actions
questions.correctAnswer: God desires justice over empty ritual sacrifices
questions.explanation: The verse emphasizes that God values righteous judgment and justice rather than mere ceremonial offerings, reflecting prophetic critique of hollow worship.

questions.question: The phrase 'everlasting covenant' in Isaiah 61:8 most closely parallels which covenant in the Pentateuch?
questions.correctAnswer: The Abrahamic covenant
questions.explanation: The 'everlasting covenant' refers to the enduring promises God made to Abraham about blessing and relationship with his descendants.

questions.question: Isaiah 61:9 says their seed shall be 'known among the Gentiles.' How does this relate to New Testament themes?
options: The inclusion of Gentiles into God's people through Christ
The continued separation of Jews and Gentiles
Gentiles remaining outsiders to God's promises
questions.correctAnswer: The inclusion of Gentiles into God's people through Christ
questions.explanation: This prophecy prefigures the New Testament theme where Gentiles are grafted into God's people, as seen in Romans 11.

questions.question: In Isaiah 61:10, what is the symbolic meaning of being 'clothed with the garments of salvation' and 'covered with the robe of righteousness'?
questions.correctAnswer: Divine vindication and justification
questions.explanation: The garments symbolize the spiritual state of salvation and righteousness imparted by God, a common biblical metaphor for justification.

questions.question: Isaiah 61:11 likens the Lord causing righteousness and praise to spring forth to which agricultural process?
options: The earth bringing forth its bud
questions.correctAnswer: The earth bringing forth its bud
questions.explanation: The verse uses the natural imagery of the earth producing buds to illustrate God’s sovereign work in bringing forth righteousness and praise.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 61 presents a messianic prophecy that Jesus later quotes at the beginning of his ministry in the Gospel of Luke.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jesus reads Isaiah 61:1-2 in Luke 4:18-19, declaring the fulfillment of this messianic prophecy in his mission.

questions.question: Isaiah 61:3 mentions 'trees of righteousness' as a metaphor. What does this typology signify in the broader biblical narrative?
options: The flourishing and stability of God's people
A reference to the Garden of Eden restoration
questions.correctAnswer: The flourishing and stability of God's people
questions.explanation: The metaphor indicates the blessed condition of God's people, rooted in righteousness and flourishing under divine care.

questions.question: In Isaiah 61:6, how does the promise 'ye shall eat the riches of the Gentiles' relate to the historical context of Israel's status among nations?
options: It symbolizes a reversal of fortune where Israel will prosper over former oppressors
A call for Israel to conquer new lands militarily
A literal feast with Gentile nations
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes a reversal of fortune where Israel will prosper over former oppressors
questions.explanation: This promise reflects the prophetic hope that Israel will be restored and enjoy prosperity previously held by Gentile nations.

theological.title: Isaiah Chapter 61 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Isaiah Chapter 61 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 61:1, what is the primary mission given to the anointed one by the Spirit of the Lord?
options: To preach good tidings to the meek
questions.correctAnswer: To preach good tidings to the meek
questions.explanation: Isaiah 61:1 states that the Lord has anointed the speaker to preach good tidings unto the meek. This mission highlights the proclamation of God's salvation to the humble and brokenhearted, consistent with Luke 4:18 where Jesus reads this passage to define His messianic mission, emphasizing the good news to the poor and freedom to captives.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 61:2 describe as being proclaimed alongside the 'acceptable year of the LORD'?
options: The day of vengeance of our God
The coming of a new king
questions.correctAnswer: The day of vengeance of our God
questions.explanation: Isaiah 61:2 speaks of proclaiming both the acceptable year of the LORD and the day of vengeance of God. This juxtaposition reveals God's dual purposes of mercy and justice, a theme echoed in Romans 12:19 and Revelation 6:10 where God’s righteous judgment is anticipated alongside His salvation.

questions.question: In Isaiah 61:3, what is given to those who mourn in Zion as a sign of God’s restoration?
options: Beauty for ashes, the oil of joy for mourning, the garment of praise for the spirit of heaviness
Gold and silver for their offerings
questions.correctAnswer: Beauty for ashes, the oil of joy for mourning, the garment of praise for the spirit of heaviness
questions.explanation: Isaiah 61:3 promises God’s people transformation from sorrow to joy and praise. This imagery of replacing ashes with beauty parallels 2 Corinthians 5:17, where believers are made new creations, and Revelation 21:4 where God wipes away all tears.

questions.question: Isaiah 61:4 speaks about rebuilding and raising up former desolations. What is the theological significance of this restoration?
options: It symbolizes God's covenant faithfulness and the eschatological renewal of His people
It refers only to physical rebuilding with no spiritual meaning
It indicates a new political kingdom without divine involvement
It predicts the permanent destruction of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes God's covenant faithfulness and the eschatological renewal of His people
questions.explanation: The rebuilding of ancient ruins in Isaiah 61:4 symbolizes God's restoration of His covenant people and the eschatological hope of renewal, as confirmed in Ezekiel 36:36 and Revelation 21:1-5, where God makes all things new and restores His creation.

questions.question: Who does Isaiah 61:5 say will stand and feed the flocks of God's people in the restored community?
options: Strangers and sons of the alien
questions.correctAnswer: Strangers and sons of the alien
questions.explanation: Isaiah 61:5 indicates that foreigners will serve the restored community, demonstrating God's inclusion of the Gentiles in His redemptive plan. This theme is echoed in Isaiah 56:6-7 and Romans 11:17-24, where Gentiles are grafted into God’s people.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 61:6, what title will God's people bear after their restoration?
questions.correctAnswer: Priests of the LORD
questions.explanation: Isaiah 61:6 describes God’s people as being called priests and ministers of God, indicating a priestly role that mediates God's presence to the nations, consistent with 1 Peter 2:9 and Revelation 1:6, which affirm the priesthood of all believers.

questions.question: What promise does Isaiah 61:7 give regarding the shame and confusion of God's people?
options: They shall receive double and everlasting joy
questions.correctAnswer: They shall receive double and everlasting joy
questions.explanation: Isaiah 61:7 promises a double portion for shame and everlasting joy, highlighting God's mercy and restoration. This double blessing is a sign of God’s covenant grace, paralleled in Zechariah 9:12 and 2 Corinthians 4:17 where affliction leads to eternal glory.

questions.question: Which attribute of God is emphasized in Isaiah 61:8 when He declares His love for judgment and hatred of robbery?
questions.correctAnswer: God’s justice and righteousness
questions.explanation: Isaiah 61:8 highlights God's commitment to justice and righteousness, rejecting injustice like robbery. This reflects the biblical portrayal of God’s holiness and moral perfection found throughout Scripture, such as Psalm 89:14 and Amos 5:24.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 61:9 say about the offspring of God’s people after restoration?
options: Their seed shall be known and blessed among the Gentiles
They shall be hidden and forgotten
questions.correctAnswer: Their seed shall be known and blessed among the Gentiles
questions.explanation: Isaiah 61:9 promises that God's people’s descendants will be recognized and blessed among the nations, illustrating the universal scope of God's covenant, consistent with Genesis 12:3 and Galatians 3:8 where blessing extends to all nations through Israel.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 61:10, how does the speaker describe the garments given by God?
options: Garments of salvation and a robe of righteousness
questions.correctAnswer: Garments of salvation and a robe of righteousness
questions.explanation: Isaiah 61:10 describes being clothed with salvation and righteousness, metaphorically portraying God's gift of justification and sanctification, consistent with Zechariah 3:3-5 and Revelation 19:8, which speak of being clothed in righteous garments.

questions.question: What analogy does Isaiah 61:11 use to describe the outworking of God's righteousness and praise?
options: The earth bringing forth its bud and garden causing seeds to spring forth
questions.correctAnswer: The earth bringing forth its bud and garden causing seeds to spring forth
questions.explanation: Isaiah 61:11 uses agricultural imagery to illustrate how God’s righteousness and praise will naturally and abundantly manifest, echoing Psalm 65:9-13 and Hosea 6:3, where divine blessing results in fruitful growth and renewal.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT part of the mission described in Isaiah 61:1-2?
options: To open the prison to those who are bound
questions.correctAnswer: To establish earthly kingdoms
questions.explanation: Isaiah 61:1-2 outlines a mission of liberation, healing, and comfort, but does not include establishing earthly kingdoms. The focus is spiritual freedom and restoration, aligning with Luke 4:18-19 and John 18:36 where Jesus distinguishes His kingdom as not of this world.

questions.question: Isaiah 61:6 mentions that God's people will 'eat the riches of the Gentiles.' What does this imply about the relationship between Israel and the nations?
options: Israel will share in the wealth and blessings of the Gentiles as a sign of God’s universal reign
Israel will conquer and oppress the Gentiles
Israel will be isolated from the Gentiles
questions.correctAnswer: Israel will share in the wealth and blessings of the Gentiles as a sign of God’s universal reign
questions.explanation: Eating the riches of the Gentiles in Isaiah 61:6 symbolizes sharing in their blessings, reflecting the inclusion of Gentiles in God's kingdom, as also seen in Psalm 2:8 and Ephesians 3:6, affirming God's plan to bless all nations through Israel.

questions.question: Isaiah 61:3 refers to those restored as 'trees of righteousness.' Theologically, what does this metaphor communicate?
options: They are firmly planted in God’s covenant and bear fruit that glorifies Him
They will be cut down like wild trees
questions.correctAnswer: They are firmly planted in God’s covenant and bear fruit that glorifies Him
questions.explanation: Calling God’s people 'trees of righteousness' in Isaiah 61:3 signifies stability, growth, and fruitfulness in righteousness, consistent with Psalm 1:3 and Jeremiah 17:7-8, which describe the blessedness of those rooted in God’s ways.

questions.question: What does the 'everlasting covenant' mentioned in Isaiah 61:8 reveal about God's character?
options: God is faithful and unchanging in His promises to His people
God’s promises are conditional and temporary
God’s covenant is only for one generation
questions.correctAnswer: God is faithful and unchanging in His promises to His people
questions.explanation: Isaiah 61:8’s reference to an everlasting covenant shows God's enduring faithfulness, as also affirmed in Genesis 9:16, Hebrews 13:8, and 2 Timothy 2:13, emphasizing the immutable nature of God and His promises.
